187.text:

192.text:

if you put a price on it you raise revenues.

204.text:

208.text:

solutions. But I think you have… we have

227.text:

232.text:
making sure that we build a sustainable and
prosperous future for our children.

We work with communities every day, whether

3613.text:
it's on parks issues and looking at, you know,
the research that's being done and how do

3619.text:
we protect parks, how do communities work
with them? So we have parks that are co-managed

3625.text:
with Inuit, which is a really amazing model,
and looking at the science there, then how

3629.text:
do we feed that science back in.
Environmental assessments. You absolutely

3634.text:
have to work with communities because they're
the ones who feel the impacts. You need to

3638.text:
understand their concerns and respond to their
concerns and look for solutions.

3643.text:
So it's a very practical thing, this, you
know, my job, where, you know, people are

3650.text:
really feeling the impact of environmental
changes, or want to see opportunities in their

3656.text:
communities, so working with communities that
are looking at clean energy. How do we support

3660.text:
them?
We're having many discussions with indigenous

3663.text:
communities in the North who are on diesel.
They want to be part of the solution. They

3667.text:
want to get off diesel, so how do we find
location solutions that'll create jobs and

3673.text:

just be top down. It's very important that

3679.text:
you engage with, you know, with communities

3684.text:

think. Like, you know, people who care about

3688.text:
the environment, they also care about jobs

3691.text:

3694.text:
you don't come in with your ideas and saying,

3699.text:
no development, or we're going to do this

3703.text:
down and really, you know, have an opportunity

3709.text:
win-win solutions.
